paper_abstract: We model a network in which messages spread by a simple directed graph G = (V, E) and a function alpha : V -> N mapping each upsilon is an element of V to a positive integer less than or equal to the indegree of upsilon. The graph G represents the individuals in the network and the communication channels between them. An individual upsilon is an element of V will be convinced of a message when at least alpha(upsilon) of its in-neighbors are convinced. Suppose we are to convince a message to the individuals by first convincing a subset of individuals, called the seeds, and then let the message spread. We study the minimum number min-seed (G, alpha) of seeds needed to convince all individuals at the end. In particular, we prove a lower bound on min-seed (G, alpha) and the NP-completeness of computing min-seed (G, alpha). We also analyze the special case, called the strict-majority scenario, where each individual is convinced of a message when more than half of its in-neighbors are convinced. For the strict-majority scenario, we prove three results. First, we show that with high probability over the Erdos-Renyi random graphs G(n, p), Omega(min{n, 1/p}) seeds are needed to convince all individuals at the end. Second, if G = (V, E) is undirected, then a set of s uniformly random samples from V convinces no more than an expected s(2 vertical bar E vertical bar + 2 vertical bar V vertical bar)vertical bar V vertical bar individuals at the end. Third, in a digraph G = (V, E) with a positive minimum indegree, one can find in polynomial (in vertical bar V vertical bar) time a set of at most (23/27)vertical bar V vertical bar seeds convincing all individuals.
